instruction: How does the newly designed multispectral imaging technique compare to traditional methods in diagnosing Ocular Surface Squamous Neoplasia (OSSN)?
Output:
The newly designed multispectral imaging technique shows promise in diagnosing Ocular Surface Squamous Neoplasia (OSSN) compared to traditional methods. The technique involves using a custom-built spectral imaging system with 38 spectral channels to obtain auto fluorescence multispectral microscopy images of biopsy specimens. Machine learning methods, specifically K nearest neighbor and Support Vector Machine classifiers, are used to automatically detect and delineate OSSN within and between patients. 

The quantitative analysis of the spectral images provides a strong multispectral signature that distinguishes neoplastic tissue from normal tissue both within each patient and between patients. The technique was able to detect OSSN in all patients investigated. The cancer margins detected by multispectral analysis were in close agreement with the margins observed in the H&E sections, indicating the accuracy of the technique.

Overall, the newly designed multispectral imaging technique, combined with machine learning methods, offers a fully automated and rapid diagnostic tool for OSSN. It provides maps of the neoplastic-non neoplastic interface, which can be used for intraoperative assessment. This suggests that the technique has the potential to be translated into future clinical applications for diagnosing OSSN.
